title: Your brain hallucinates your conscious reality - Anil Seth

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by saying "I ceased to exist"?

options.label: A
options.text: That he lost consciousness due to anesthesia.

options.label: B
options.text: That he was experiencing a vivid dream.

options.label: C
options.text: That he was in a state of deep meditation.

options.label: D
options.text: That he was experiencing a sense of detachment from his body.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between waking up from a deep sleep and waking up from anesthesia?

options.label: A
options.text: The time it takes to wake up.

options.label: B
options.text: The sense of time that has passed.

options.label: D
options.text: The sense of continuity between then and now.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about the nature of consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: That consciousness is a product of the brain's activity.

options.label: B
options.text: That consciousness is a separate entity from the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: That consciousness is a product of the body's activity.

options.label: D
options.text: That consciousness is a product of the environment.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between perception and hallucination?

options.label: A
options.text: Perception is a passive process, while hallucination is an active process.

options.label: B
options.text: Perception is a controlled process, while hallucination is an uncontrolled process.

options.label: C
options.text: Perception is a process of figuring out what's there, while hallucination is a process of creating what's not there.

options.label: D
options.text: Perception is a process of creating what's not there, while hallucination is a process of figuring out what's there.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's explanation for the rubber hand illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain's ability to perceive the rubber hand as part of the body is due to the similarity between the rubber hand and the real hand.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's ability to perceive the rubber hand as part of the body is due to the congruence between seeing touch and feeling touch on the rubber hand.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain's ability to perceive the rubber hand as part of the body is due to the brain's prediction that the rubber hand is part of the body.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's ability to perceive the rubber hand as part of the body is due to the brain's ability to ignore the differences between the rubber hand and the real hand.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between our experiences of the world around us and our experiences of our bodies from within?

options.label: A
options.text: Our experiences of the world around us are more subjective than our experiences of our bodies from within.

options.label: B
options.text: Our experiences of the world around us are more objective than our experiences of our bodies from within.

options.label: C
options.text: Our experiences of the world around us are more about control and regulation than our experiences of our bodies from within.

options.label: D
options.text: Our experiences of our bodies from within are more about figuring out what's there than our experiences of the world around us.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main implication of the idea that our experiences of the world and ourselves are kinds of controlled hallucinations?

options.label: A
options.text: That we can reduce the complexity of our experiences to a set of simple rules.

options.label: B
options.text: That we can upload our consciousness to a computer.

options.label: C
options.text: That we can understand ourselves and the world around us in a more fundamental way.

options.label: D
options.text: That we can ignore the biological mechanisms that underlie our experiences.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument about the nature of self and consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: That self and consciousness are separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: That self and consciousness are products of the brain's activity.

options.label: C
options.text: That self and consciousness are products of the body's activity.

options.label: D
options.text: That self and consciousness are products of the environment.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between our individual inner universes and the universe as a whole?

options.label: A
options.text: Our individual inner universes are more complex than the universe as a whole.

options.label: B
options.text: Our individual inner universes are more subjective than the universe as a whole.

options.label: C
options.text: Our individual inner universes are more biological than the universe as a whole.

options.label: D
options.text: Our individual inner universes are more unique than the universe as a whole.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message about the nature of consciousness and the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: That consciousness is a product of the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: That consciousness is a product of the brain's activity.

options.label: C
options.text: That we are separate from the rest of nature.

options.label: D
options.text: That we are part of and not apart from the rest of nature.

options.text: Each box must contain between 5 and 15 rubies, and the merchant must give away at least 10 rubies.

options.text: Each box must contain an odd number of rubies, and the merchant must give away at least 20 rubies.

multiple-choice.question: What strategy should the advisor use to guarantee the largest possible fine for the merchant?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Negotiate with the merchant to reduce the fine.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Does time exist? - Andrew Zimmerman Jones

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known method of time measurement?

options.label: A
options.text: Observations of the cycles of the natural world, using patterns of changes from day to night and season to season to build calendars.

options.label: C
options.text: Observing the movement of celestial bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: Measuring the passage of time using atomic clocks.

multiple-choice.question: According to Einstein's theory of relativity, does time pass at the same rate for everyone?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it always passes at the same rate for everyone.

options.label: B
options.text: No, it doesn't always pass at the same rate for people in different situations.

options.label: D
options.text: Only for people in a vacuum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the direction of time's arrow?
What is the property of the universe that defines the direction of time's arrow?

options.label: C
options.text: The gain of disorder, or entropy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of theoretical physics over the last half century?

options.label: A
options.text: To reconcile the two sets of equations that govern physics.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a new theory of everything.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the behavior of very large things.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Wheeler-DeWitt equation?

options.label: A
options.text: A fundamental equation that describes the behavior of very large things.

options.label: B
options.text: A fundamental equation that explains the very small.

options.label: C
options.text: A speculative equation that doesn't include time.

options.label: D
options.text: A proven equation that describes the passage of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is an emergent property?

options.label: A
options.text: A property that exists in individual pieces of a system.

options.label: B
options.text: A property that exists for the system as a whole.

options.label: C
options.text: A property that is not observable.

options.label: D
options.text: A property that is not measurable.

multiple-choice.question: How do still images create the illusion of movement?

options.label: A
options.text: By changing or containing the passage of time.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a series of still images that appear to have a fluid, continuous change between them.

options.label: C
options.text: By flipping through the images fast enough.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of both A and B.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current understanding of time in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: That time is a fundamental property of the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: That time is an emergent property of the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: That time is an illusion generated by the limitations of the way we perceive the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: That time is not a property of the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the reconciliation of the two sets of equations that govern physics?

options.label: A
options.text: That it has been fully achieved.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is still an ongoing process.

title: What happens in your body when you swallow gum?

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B
